choices.text: Vitamin D intoxication
Vitamin A intoxication
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causing hypercalcemia is least likely to respond to glucocorticoid therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)

 

Option D:

 

Glucocorticoids work by reducing the production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol) by activated macrophages and decreasing intestinal calcium absorption. They are effective in treating hypercalcemia caused by:

 

  • Vitamin D intoxication: Excess vitamin D leads to increased intestinal calcium absorption, which can be countered by glucocorticoids.
  • Vitamin A intoxication: Glucocorticoids can counteract the bone resorption caused by excess vitamin A.
  • Sarcoidosis: Activated macrophages in granulomas produce excess calcitriol, and glucocorticoids reduce this production.

 

However, glucocorticoids are not typically effective in treating hypercalcemia caused by non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). This type of hypercalcemia is usually due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) by the tumor, which glucocorticoids do not inhibit.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin D intoxication: Glucocorticoids are a standard treatment for this condition.

 

Option B. Vitamin A intoxication: Glucocorticoids are effective in treating hypercalcemia related to vitamin A intoxication.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Glucocorticoids are a first-line treatment for hypercalcemia caused by sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The condition causing hypercalcemia that is least likely to respond to glucocorticoid therapy is non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

choices.text: IV Zoledronic acid

questions.text: A patient with breast cancer presents with dehydration and a serum calcium of 17 mg/dL. Which of the following is not a useful therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Calcitonin

 

Option D:

 

While calcitonin can initially lower serum calcium levels, its effect is transient due to tachyphylaxis (rapidly diminishing response to repeated doses). In a case of severe hypercalcemia (calcium >14 mg/dL), such as in this patient with breast cancer, more potent and longer-lasting therapies are required.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IV Fluids: Aggressive hydration with isotonic saline is essential to restore intravascular volume and promote renal calcium excretion.

 

Option B. s.c Denosumab: Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody targeting RANKL, is a potent inhibitor of osteoclast activity and bone resorption, making it effective in malignancy-associated hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. IV Zoledronic Acid: Zoledronic acid, a bisphosphonate, is another potent inhibitor of bone resorption and is commonly used in the management of hypercalcemia of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with severe hypercalcemia due to malignancy, IV Calcitonin is not as useful due to its transient effect and development of tachyphylaxis.

choices.text: Vitamin D intoxication

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of osteoporosis presents with fatigue, nausea, and polyuria. Labs reveal hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and elevated creatinine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Milk-alkali syndrome

 

Option B:

 

The combination of hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and renal failure in this patient is highly suggestive of milk-alkali syndrome. This condition is caused by excessive intake of calcium and absorbable alkali (milk/calcium carbonate), which is common in osteoporosis.
Risk is higher if the patient has co-existing renal failure (due to reduced calcium excretion).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Primary hyperparathyroidism: While it can cause hypercalcemia, it is not typically associated with metabolic alkalosis and renal impairment.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Can cause hypercalcemia but is usually associated with granulomatous inflammation and elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels.

 

Option D. Vitamin D intoxication: While it can cause hypercalcemia, it is not usually associated with metabolic alkalosis and renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

The most likely cause of hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and renal impairment in an elderly woman with osteoporosis is milk-alkali syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with short stature, round face, obesity, shortened fourth and fifth metacarpals, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1A (PHP1A)

 

Option B:

 

The child's presentation is characteristic of Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO), which is a key feature of PHP1A. AHO includes short stature, round face, obesity, brachydactyly (shortened metacarpals/metatarsals), and sometimes intellectual disability.

 

The laboratory findings of hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, along with elevated PTH levels, are consistent with PTH resistance, a hallmark of pseudohypoparathyroidism.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism (PPHP): Individuals with PPHP have AHO features but normal calcium, phosphate, and PTH levels. They do not exhibit hormone resistance.

 

Option C. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1B (PHP1B): While PHP1B also presents with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, it is less likely to be associated with the full spectrum of AHO features.

 

Option D. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 2 (PHP2): PHP2 is characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia with normal urinary cAMP response to PTH, but it does not typically present with AHO features.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The child's presentation with short stature, round face, obesity, shortened fourth and fifth metacarpals, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia is characteristic of Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO), which is associated with PHP1A.

questions.text: A patient had a hip fracture and was started on a bone protective agent. However, after 3 years of use, the patient lost follow-up and stopped therapy. Within 3 months of stopping treatment, the patient developed a new vertebral fracture. What is the drug that was likely given initially and stopped?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denosumab

 

Option C:

 

Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits RANKL, a key factor in osteoclast formation and function. While it is effective in reducing bone resorption and increasing bone density, its effects are rapidly reversible upon discontinuation. When denosumab is stopped, there can be a rebound increase in bone turnover and a significant loss of bone density, leading to an increased risk of fractures, particularly vertebral fractures, within a short period.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Zoledronate and Option B. Alendronate: These are bisphosphonates, which have a longer-lasting effect on bone remodeling than denosumab. While there can be a gradual loss of bone density after discontinuing bisphosphonates, it is not as rapid or dramatic as the rebound effect seen with denosumab.

 

Option D. Raloxifene: This is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) with a milder effect on bone density compared to bisphosphonates and denosumab. Its discontinuation is not typically associated with a rapid increase in fracture risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Denosumab is associated with a rapid rebound increase in bone turnover and risk of fractures upon discontinuation, which explains the new vertebral fracture within three months of stopping the drug.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presented with a Colles' fracture. She has diabetes and suffered from an MI 2 years ago and a stroke a year ago. Which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate for her osteoporosis treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alendronate

 

Option B:

 

Alendronate is a bisphosphonate, a class of drugs that are the first-line treatment for osteoporosis in most patients. It has been shown to reduce the risk of both vertebral and non-vertebral fractures, including Colles' fractures. It is well-tolerated in most patients and has a good safety profile.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Strontium ranelate: Not available in the US and has a potential risk of cardiovascular events, which would be a concern in this patient with a history of MI and stroke.

 

Option C. Romosozumab: While effective in reducing fractures, it has a higher cost and is usually reserved for patients with severe osteoporosis who have failed other treatments. Its safety profile in patients with cardiovascular disease is not yet fully established.

 

Option D. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a SERM that is primarily effective in reducing vertebral fractures and has limited data on preventing non-vertebral fractures like Colles' fractures. Additionally, it carries a risk of thromboembolic events which might be a concern in this patient (but note that Raloxifene does not increase CV risk like HRT).

 

Fracture reduction data:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alendronate is effective for reducing the risk of fractures and is generally well-tolerated, making it the most appropriate choice for a patient with a history of cardiovascular events and a Colles' fracture.

choices.text: Equine estrogen with medroxyprogesterone

questions.text: A 52-year-old depressed woman presents with a T-score of -2.8 on DEXA scan and severe hot flashes. She has a past history of hysterectomy 6 years ago. Which of the following would be the most suitable treatment for this patient to prevent fractures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transdermal estrogen

 

Option A:

 

  • Transdermal estrogen is the most suitable option because it addresses both the patient's osteoporosis (T-score -2.8) and severe hot flashes, a common symptom of menopause. Estrogen therapy is effective in preventing bone loss and reducing fracture risk in postmenopausal women, while also providing relief from menopausal symptoms.
  • Since the patient has undergone a hysterectomy, she does not require progestin to protect the endometrium, making estrogen-only therapy the preferred choice.
  • Risks and benefits of estrogen-progestin combinations is shown -

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Equine estrogen with medroxyprogesterone: While this combination therapy is effective for osteoporosis and hot flashes, it is not necessary for women who have had a hysterectomy as it includes progestin, which is used to protect the endometrium in women with a uterus. Addition of progestin can potentially increase the risk of breast cancer as well.

 

Option C. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that can be used to prevent osteoporosis. However, it can worsen hot flashes and is not the ideal choice for this patient.

 

Option D. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that stimulates bone formation. While effective for osteoporosis, it does not address menopausal symptoms and is generally reserved for patients with severe osteoporosis who have failed other treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transdermal estrogen is effective for both osteoporosis and severe hot flashes, and since the patient has had a hysterectomy, she does not need progestin.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with acute chest pain for the last 3 hours. Aspirin and clopidogrel was given in the ambulance. ECG is taken in ER and shown below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enoxaparin

 

Option C:

 

ECG shows widespread ST segment depression, suggesting a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) without ST-elevation (NSTE-ACS). In patients with suspected NSTE-ACS, early administration of anticoagulation is crucial to prevent further thrombus formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent used in STEMI and not in NSTE-ACS.

 

Option B. Tirofiban: GpIIb/IIIa inhibitor used primarily during PCI under special circumstances.

 

Option D. Emergent Coronary angiography: While angiography is crucial to confirm the diagnosis and guide further management, immediate anticoagulation with enoxaparin should be initiated first. In this patient with ST depression (a high risk factor), URGENT coronary angiography is optimal (< 24h) rather than immediate (< 2h).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with suspected NSTE-ACS, early administration of enoxaparin is crucial to prevent further thrombus formation while awaiting coronary angiography.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with exertional chest pain and a positive stress test undergoes angiography revealing complex multivessel coronary artery disease (CAD) involving the left main. He has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 42%. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)

 

Option A:

 

CABG is the preferred revascularization strategy for patients with complex multivessel CAD, especially involving the left main, and with reduced LVEF. It offers superior survival benefits compared to medical therapy alone or PCI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Medical therapy: Insufficient for complex CAD and reduced LVEF, carries a higher risk of adverse events.

 

Option C. Viability testing: Not necessary before revascularization in this scenario.

 

Option D. PCI: Less favorable than CABG for complex multivessel disease, especially with left main involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with multivessel coronary artery disease, coronary artery bypass grafting is associated with enhanced survival compared with medical therapy alone.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with stable angina and aspirin allergy is undergoing lifestyle counseling and antianginal therapy. What is the most appropriate cardioprotective treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clopidogrel

 

Option A:

 

Clopidogrel is recommended for secondary prevention in patients with stable ischemic heart disease who are intolerant or allergic to aspirin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Low-dose aspirin: Contraindicated due to aspirin allergy.

 

Option C. Prasugrel and Option D. Ticagrelor: More potent antiplatelet agents, typically used in acute coronary syndrome or after PCI, not as monotherapy for stable angina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All patients with stable ischemic heart disease should receive guideline-directed therapies consisting of lifestyle modification, cardioprotective therapy, and antianginal medication. Patients with stable ischemic heart disease should receive antiplatelet therapy (low-dose aspirin or clopidogrel in aspirin-intolerant patients) for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus received a drug-eluting stent for non-ST elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS). She was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and clopidogrel. What is the recommended minimum duration of her antiplatelet therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12 months

 

Option D:

 

In patients with diabetes who have received a drug-eluting stent for NSTE-ACS, the recommended minimum duration of DAPT (aspirin plus a P2Y12 inhibitor like clopidogrel) is 12 months. This is due to the increased risk of stent thrombosis and major adverse cardiovascular events in patients with diabetes compared to those without.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 1 month: This duration is too short and would significantly increase the risk of stent thrombosis.

 

Option B. 3 months: While some studies suggest shorter durations may be safe in select patients, the standard recommendation for patients with diabetes is 12 months.

 

Option C. 6 months: This is the minimum duration for patients without diabetes who have received a drug-eluting stent for ACS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the recommended duration of dual antiplatelet therapy in patients with diabetes who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stents for acute coronary syndrome.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with persistent angina despite maximally tolerated antianginal therapy. He has orthostatic hypotension and current BP and PR are 100/60 mm Hg and 54/min respectively. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coronary angiography

 

Option C:

 

Coronary angiography is the most appropriate step to assess for obstructive coronary artery disease and guide potential revascularization to improve symptoms and quality of life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Addition of Clopidogrel: Not indicated for stable angina without recent revascularization.

 

Option B. Addition of Isosorbide mononitrate: Adding more antianginal medication may not be helpful if the patient is already on maximally tolerated doses. Addition of nitrate in this patient may worsen orthostatic hypotension.

 

Option D. Exercise echocardiography: May provide prognostic information but doesn't identify lesions for revascularization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of persistent symptoms despite maximally tolerated medical therapy, invasive imaging for revascularization assessment is appropriate to improve symptom status and quality of life.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation, diabetes, and peripheral artery disease presents with acute left leg pain, absent pulses, and cold, mottled skin. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unfractionated heparin

 

Option C:

 

This patient presents with acute limb ischemia (ALI). Immediate anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin is crucial to prevent further thrombus propagation while awaiting definitive intervention (angiography).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Angiography: Essential for diagnosis and planning revascularization, but anticoagulation should be started first.

 

Option B. Apixaban: Oral anticoagulant, not appropriate in the acute setting of ALI.

 

Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography: Not indicated for ALI, which is an arterial problem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treat acute limb ischemia with anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical history presents with frequent, bothersome palpitations that subside with exercise and in the nights. ECG is shown. Echo and baseline lab tests including CBC and TFT are normal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propranolol

 

Option C:

 

The patient has symptomatic premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) that are bothersome. Beta-blockers are the first-line treatment for symptomatic PVCs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Antiarrhythmic drug with potential toxicity, not first-line for simple PVCs.

 

Option B. Exercise ECG: Not helpful for diagnosing PVCs.

 

Option D. Reassurance: Not sufficient for bothersome symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-blockers are the first-line treatment for symptomatic PVCs in patients without structural heart disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with recurrent chest pain and elevated troponin. ECG is shown. remains in pain despite aspirin, clopidogrel, heparin, and nitroglycerin. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urgent coronary angiography

 

Option D:

 

This patient has NSTE-ACS with refractory angina despite medical therapy. Urgent coronary angiography is indicated to identify the culprit lesion and potentially perform revascularization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: May be helpful, but not the immediate priority.

 

Option B. Eplerenone: Indicated in certain post-MI patients, but not the immediate priority for refractory angina.

 

Option C. Oxygen per nasal cannula: Indicated only if the patient is hypoxic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urgent or immediate diagnostic angiography with intent to perform revascularization is indicated in patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and aortofemoral bypass surgery 2 years ago has an HbA1c of 7.1%. His current medications are metformin, atenolol, ramipril, amlodipine, aspirin, rivaroxaban, and atorvastatin. Which medication is most appropriate to add for cardiovascular risk reduction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liraglutide

 

Option B:

 

GLP-1 receptor agonists like liraglutide have been shown to reduce cardiovascular events in patients with type 2 diabetes and established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), which this patient has due to his history of bypass surgery. Liraglutide also promotes weight loss, which can be beneficial for this patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Clopidogrel: Patient is already on rivaroxaban and aspirin. Addition of clopidogrel would not provide any additional benefit and only increase the bleeding risk.

 

Option C. Niacin: No longer recommended for routine use due to lack of benefit and side effects.

 

Option D. Pramlintide: Amylin analog used for glycemic control, no proven cardiovascular benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors and glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists are associated with reduced rates of adverse cardiovascular events, including stroke, myocardial infarction, and cardiovascular death, compared with placebo.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and a history of stroke is on aspirin, metformin, olmesartan, and rosuvastatin. His LDL-C is 66 mg/dL, HDL-C is 28 mg/dL and HbA1c is 6.8%. What additional medication should be considered for CV risk reduction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Empagliflozin

 

Option A:

 

SGLT2 inhibitors like empagliflozin have been shown to reduce cardiovascular events in patients with type 2 diabetes and established ASCVD. They are recommended as part of a comprehensive cardiovascular risk reduction strategy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Not indicated as LDL cholesterol is already well-controlled.

 

Option C. Niacin: Can increase HDL but no longer recommended for routine use due to lack of benefit and side effects.

 

Option D. No changes in management: Inadequate as SGLT2 inhibitors provide additional CV benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consider adding SGLT2 inhibitors to the treatment regimen for patients with type 2 diabetes and established ASCVD to reduce CV risk.

choices.text: Reduce isosorbide mononitrate dosage to once daily

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with CAD and diabetes mellitus experiences worsening angina. He is currently on ramipril, diltiazem, metformin, atorvastatin and isosorbide mononitrate twice daily. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reduce isosorbide mononitrate dosage to once daily

 

Option C:

 

This patient is likely experiencing nitrate tolerance, a common side effect of long-acting nitrates like isosorbide mononitrate. Reducing the frequency to once daily with a nitrate-free interval helps restore nitrate efficacy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adding amlodipine: Not the first-line option when nitrate tolerance is suspected.

 

Option B. Decreasing lisinopril: Not indicated as blood pressure is controlled.

 

Option D. Repeat coronary angiography: Not necessary unless there is a suspicion of new coronary lesions or progression of existing ones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-acting nitrates provide a constant level of vasodilation and symptom relief throughout the day, but a nitrate-free interval is required to avoid tolerance.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with inferior STEMI and he is successfully treated with PCI. He has a history of paroxysmal AF and was taking flecainide. He was also started on rivaroxaban, metoprolol, and ramipril post PCI. He is currently asymptomatic and now planned for discharge from the hospital. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discontinue flecainide

 

Option B:

 

This patient has ischemic heart disease and previously diagnosed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF). Amiodarone, dofetilide, flecainide, propafenone, sotalol, and dronedarone may be used to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with AF. Antiarrhythmic drug selection is guided by the patient's comorbid conditions and safety considerations. Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic agent and, along with propafenone, is absolutely contraindicated in patients with ischemic heart disease, given the increased risk for ventricular arrhythmias in this population. This patient also has evidence of left ventricular (LV) dysfunction on a post–myocardial infarction echocardiogram, which may be due to infarcted myocardium and may lead to increased long-term risk for ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ambulatory ECG monitoring: Helpful for assessing AF burden but doesn't address the contraindication of flecainide.

 

Option C. Discontinue metoprolol: Not ideal as it's essential for managing ischemic heart disease.

 

Option D. Exercise stress testing: Not recommended immediately post-MI, especially with existing conduction abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class IC antiarrhythmics like flecainide are C/I in patients with ischemic heart disease due to an increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias and death.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with a history of hypertension and CAD presents with recurrent atrial flutter. He is on dabigatran, metoprolol, ramipril, aspirin, and atorvastatin. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Catheter ablation

 

Option D:

 

Catheter ablation is the definitive treatment for typical atrial flutter, with a high success rate (> 95%) and low complication rate. It's the most appropriate option for this patient with recurrent symptomatic atrial flutter despite rate control.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Antiarrhythmic drug with potential for toxicity, not the first-line treatment.

 

Option B. Cardiac catheterization: Not needed for treating atrial flutter at this point.

 

Option C. Cardioversion: May provide temporary relief but is not definitive treatment in this case where the patient is experiencing recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catheter ablation is the best treatment for recurrent typical atrial flutter.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with ischemic cardiomyopathy presents with progressive dyspnea, edema and confusion. Her medications include low-dose aspirin, furosemide, carvedilol, ramipril, digoxin, and spironolactone. Her BP is 84/52 mm Hg, PR is 118/min, RR is 28/min and SpO2 is 95 in room air. Her reports are shown below.

 

ALT - 172 U/L, AST - 163 U/L, S. Creatinine - 2.9 mg/dL , S. K - 4.7 mEq/L, S. Na - 132 mEq/L & S. Digoxin - 0.3 ng/mL. 

 

What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Start Nonadrenaline

 

Option D:

 

This patient has cardiogenic shock due to acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). Noradrenaline (NA), an inotrope, is indicated to improve cardiac output in this scenario. Once NA is added, other inotropes like dobutamine and/or milrinone can be added sequentially to ensure adequate support.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increase carvedilol: Beta-blockers are contraindicated in cardiogenic shock.

 

Option B. Increase digoxin: Not effective in cardiogenic shock and potentially harmful with AKI.

 

Option C. Increase lisinopril: Afterload reduction may be considered later, but inotropic support is the priority in this patient with cardiogenic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with cardiogenic shock, inotropes such as Noradrenaline, dobutamine or milrinone may be considered to improve cardiac function.

choices.text: Discontinue aspirin and begin oral anticoagulation

questions.text: A 75-year-old asymptomatic woman with CAD, diabetes and hypertension presents with palpitations. ECG shows AF. She is on metoprolol, telmisartan, aspirin, and atorvastatin. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Discontinue aspirin and begin oral anticoagulation

 

Option C:

 

The patient has AF and is at high risk for stroke (CHA2DS2-VASc score of 5). Oral anticoagulation is indicated for stroke prevention. Aspirin should be discontinued as it provides no additional benefit and increases bleeding risk when combined with anticoagulants.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adding clopidogrel: Not indicated, as the patient has no recent ACS or stent.

 

Option B. Adding oral anticoagulation without discontinuing aspirin: Increases bleeding risk.

 

Option D. No change in therapy: Inadequate as the patient needs anticoagulation for stroke prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For most patients with high-risk atrial fibrillation and stable coronary artery disease, oral anticoagulation therapy without an antiplatelet agent is sufficient for prevention of both acute coronary syndromes and thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with diabetes and PAD has a right foot ulcer and feeble pulses. Ankle Brachial Index (ABI) on the right is 1.65. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toe-brachial index (TBI)

 

Option C:

 

When the ABI is uninterpretable due to non-compressible vessels (ABI >1.40), the toe-brachial index (TBI) is a reliable alternative to assess for peripheral arterial disease (PAD). A TBI <0.70 indicates significant PAD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Exercise ABI: Not useful when resting ABI is uninterpretable.

 

Option B. Lower Extremity CT angiography: Helpful for planning revascularization, but TBI is the more appropriate initial test in this scenario.

 

Option D. Venous duplex ultrasonography: Evaluates for venous disease, not arterial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toe-brachial index (TBI) is useful in diagnosing PAD when ankle-brachial index (ABI) is uninterpretable due to non-compressible vessels.

questions.text: 52-year-old woman complains of chest tightness after walking for 2-3 km and relieved with rest.  Her resting ECG is normal. She is known case of hypertension and dyslipidemia and currently taking ramipril and atorvastatin. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exercise electrocardiography

 

Option C:

 

In patients with a normal resting ECG and the ability to exercise, exercise ECG is the recommended initial test for evaluating suspected coronary artery disease (CAD). It provides valuable information about exercise capacity and ischemic response.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adenosine single-photon emission CT: Reserved for patients who cannot exercise or have uninterpretable ECGs.

 

Option B. Coronary artery calcium scoring: Used for risk stratification in asymptomatic patients especially to know the need for a statin. The patient is already on atorvastatin.

 

Option D. Stress echocardiography: Can be considered if exercise ECG is inconclusive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exercise ECG is the first-line test for evaluating suspected CAD in patients with typical angina and a normal resting ECG.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 20%) and NYHA class III heart failure is on maximally tolerated doses of ACE inhibitor, furosemide, and empagliflozin. ECG shows LBBB with a QRS duration of 130 ms. What is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Add carvedilol

 

Option A:

 

Beta-blockers are part of guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) for HFrEF and should be added to the patient's regimen. While CRT might be considered in the future if symptoms persist despite optimal medical therapy, adding a beta-blocker is the most appropriate initial step. 

 

Current GDMT for HFrEF includes ARNi/ACEi or ARB, Beta blockers, MRA and SGLT2i.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Add Ivabradine: Indicated only after maximally tolerated beta-blocker dose.

 

Option D. CRT-D: Considered if LVEF remains ≤35%, QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II-IV symptoms despite optimal medical therapy.

 

Option C. Add digoxin: Considered for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with LVEF ≤35% despite optimal medical therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initiate beta-blocker therapy in patients with HFrEF who are not already on it, as part of guideline-directed medical therapy.

choices.text: Repeat CT angiography in 12 hours

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents with acute type B aortic dissection involving the descending thoracic aorta with a maximal aortic diameter of 6.8 cm. Her BP is 173/99 mm Hg and PR is 90/min. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV labetalol

 

Option C:

 

In acute type B aortic dissection, the immediate priority is to aggressively control blood pressure and heart rate to limit the propagation of the dissection. IV labetalol is a combined alpha- and beta-blocker that is effective in rapidly reducing blood pressure and heart rate, making it the most appropriate initial management in this scenario.

 

While surgery or endovascular stenting may be indicated in the future, they are not the immediate priority. The patient should be stabilized first with medical management before considering invasive interventions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immediate endovascular stenting: Endovascular stenting can be used to treat patients with descending aortic aneurysms; however, there is scant evidence to support this as an initial treatment option for aneurysm with dissection. After medical stabilization, thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) with stent grafting can be used; typical indications include descending aortic aneurysm diameter greater than 6.0 cm, rapid growth (>0.5 cm/year), or end-organ damage. TEVAR has the advantage over surgical operation of lower morbidity and shorter hospital stay, although there may be complications, including stroke, spinal ischemia, and aortic graft endoleaks. This patient should be treated with stent implantation only after medical stabilization.

 

Option B. Immediate open surgical repair: Open surgical repair of the descending aorta is not recommended in patients with uncomplicated type B aortic dissection because of high rates of morbidity (such as paraplegia) and mortality. This patient has no signs or symptoms of complications that would prompt immediate surgical repair.

 

Option D. Repeat CT angiography in 12 hours: Repeat CT angiography at 12 hours is not indicated unless the patient does not stabilize with medical therapy. Serial imaging (usually magnetic resonance angiography) is typically performed in asymptomatic patients at the time of discharge and then periodically in patients who do not have an indication for aneurysmal repair to screen for extension or recurrence of the dissection, aneurysm formation, and leakage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with uncomplicated type B aortic dissection may be initially treated with medical therapy, including β-blockers, sodium nitroprusside, and opioids.

choices.text: Discontinue clopidogrel and aspirin in 11 months

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman had a drug-eluting stent (DES) for chronic stable angina 1 month ago. She is currently on aspirin and clopidogrel. She is a known case of hypertension, dyslipidaemia, CKD and peptic ulcer disease and was on medications for the same. She wants to minimize DAPT in view of her age and comorbidities. How long should she continue DAPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discontinue clopidogrel in 5 months

 

Option B:

 

Guidelines suggest a minimum of 6 months of DAPT after elective DES placement. Given this patient's high bleeding risk, it is reasonable to discontinue clopidogrel after 6 months (5 additional months) while continuing aspirin indefinitely for secondary prevention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Discontinuing clopidogrel in 1 month can be done in case of bare metal stents (BMS) and not DES.

 

Option C. 12 months of DAPT is recommended in patient with ACS.

 

Option D. Aspirin should be continued indefinitely in patients with CAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dual antiplatelet therapy is recommended for at least 6 months after drug-eluting stent placement for treatment of stable angina.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with recent post-CABG (coronary artery bypass graft) status presents with chest pain. On arrival, his blood pressure is 60/30 mmHg with a heart rate of 30/min. The ECG shows a narrow complex arrhythmia. The patient has already received three boluses of IV atropine. While awaiting transcutaneous pacing, which of the following is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV Dopamine

 

Option C:

 

The patient is experiencing symptomatic bradycardia (low heart rate) with severe hypotension, likely due to a post-operative complication. The maximum dose of atropine has already been given with no adequate response. The next best step is cardiac pacing. But while awaiting pacing, one can try chronotropic drugs like dopamine, epinephrine in the ER.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Another bolus of atropine: As per ACLS guidelines, a maximum of three boluses of atropine are recommended for symptomatic bradycardia. Further doses are unlikely to be effective.

 

Option B. IV Norepinephrine: While norepinephrine is a potent vasopressor, it can also worsen bradycardia due to its reflex bradycardia effect (baroreceptor response).

 

Opion D. IV Dobutamine: Dobutamine primarily acts on beta-1 receptors, increasing heart rate and contractility, but it can also cause vasodilation (beta-2 effects), potentially worsening hypotension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronotropic drugs like dopamine can be tried while awaiting pacing in symptomatic bradycardia with hypotension, especially when atropine has been ineffective.

choices.text: Cardiac magnetic resonance perfusion scan

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive tests has the best accuracy in detecting coronary stenosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coronary CT angiography

 

Option B:

 

Accuracy in diagnostic tests is often determined by considering both sensitivity and specificity. Coronary CT angiography is the most accurate as it has the highest sensitivity and specificity.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CMR perfusion have high sensitivity, but their specificity is not as high as Coronary CTA, meaning they might produce more false-positive results.

 

Option D. Exercise echocardiography and Option C. SPECT MPI have lower sensitivity and specificity than Coronary CTA, indicating a higher chance of both false negatives and false positives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronary CTA is a highly accurate non-invasive test for detecting coronary stenosis due to its excellent sensitivity and specificity. It is a valuable tool for diagnosing and evaluating CAD.

choices.text: Metoprolol 5 mg IV

questions.text: A 46-year-old man with bacterial pneumonia experiences a sudden lightheadedness. His BP is stable, and the rhythm strip is shown. Which of the following is most likely to lead to sustained improvement in heart rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metoprolol 5 mg IV

 

Option C:

 

This patient has focal atrial tachycardia. Focal atrial tachycardia (FAT) accounts for ~10% of PSVTs in patients referred for catheter ablation (most common is AVNRT responsible for ~60% of PSVTs).

 

The arrows (which are a nice clue in the question!) indicate the ectopic atrial activity. While one could consider that this might be sinus tachycardia, the rate far exceeds the patient’s maximal predicted heart rate (220 – age) and obviates the possibility of any sinus rhythm. Any maneuver or pharmacologic therapy aimed at producing transient atrioventricular (AV) nodal block (e.g., Valsalva, carotid massage, adenosine) may briefly slow the ventricular response. However, since focal atrial tachycardia does not rely on the AV node for continuation it is rare that transient AV nodal block will terminate the arrhythmia. Beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers can lead to sustained improvement in heart rate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adenosine 6 mg IV: Primarily used for supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and may not be effective in FAT.

 

Option B. Carotid body massage: A vagal maneuver that may temporarily slow the heart rate but is not a definitive treatment.

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: A vagal maneuver that may temporarily slow the heart rate but is not a definitive treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Focal atrial tachycardia is not dependent on the AV node and beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine CCBs are the preferred treatment options for rate control.

questions.text: You are called to the ER for a young patient in cardiac arrest during exercise. ECG showed bidirectional VT and it was cardioverted immediately. ECG post-cardioversion is normal. 2D Echo and cardiac MRI are also normal. Mutations in which protein are responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium ryanodine receptor

 

Option A:

 

The patient's young age, cardiac arrest during exercise (with bidirectional VT), normal resting ECG and normal structural heart on imaging strongly suggest CPVT.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Desmosomal proteins: Mutations in desmosomal proteins cause arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC), which is a structural heart disease.

 

Option C. Potassium channel: Mutations in potassium channels can cause long QT syndrome. In this case resting ECG would have showed long QTc.

 

Option D. Sarcomere proteins: Mutations in sarcomere proteins cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which would have resulted in structural heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize bidirectional VT as a hallmark of CPVT, an inherited arrhythmia syndrome caused by mutations in the cardiac ryanodine receptor (RyR2).

choices.text: Two anginal episode in 24 hours.
All of the above confer increased risk.

questions.text: You are seeing a 75-year-old man admitted for non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction. He has a history of CAD and takes daily aspirin. He's had multiple angina episodes in the past few days, has ST-segment depression on ECG, and elevated troponin. Which of the following details does NOT confer increased risk of poor outcomes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above confer increased risk.

 

Option D:

 

Patients with documented non–ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome (ACS) exhibit a wide spectrum of early (30 days) risk of death, ranging from 1 to 10%, and a recurrent ACS rate of 5–15% during the first year.

 

Assessment of risk can be accomplished by clinical risk scoring systems such as that developed from the Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) Trials, which includes seven independent risk factors (age ≥65 years, 3 or more of the traditional risk factors for CAD, known history of CAD or coronary stenosis ≥ 50%, daily aspirin use in the prior week, more than one anginal episode in the past 24 hours, ST-segment deviation of at least 0.5 mm, and an elevated cardiac specific biomarker above the upper limit of normal).

 

Additional risk factors include diabetes, LV dysfunction, renal dysfunction, and elevated BNP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Two anginal episode in 24 hours: High risk indicating loss of ischemic preconditioning and an active/ongoing ischemia.

 

Option B. Age: Advanced age is the SINGLE most important risk factor in ACS. 

 

Option C. Daily aspirin use: While aspirin is cardioprotective, ACS despite use of aspirin indicates high thrombus burden and hence, high risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TIMI score for NSTE-ACS is important!

choices.text: Segmental lower extremity blood pressure testing

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with progressive bilateral calf pain that worsens with walking and improves with rest. He has normal resting ankle-brachial index (ABI) values. What is the most appropriate next test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exercise ankle-brachial index (ABI) testing

 

Option A:

 

Exercise ABI testing is indicated in patients with normal or borderline resting ABI but with symptoms suggestive of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It can reveal a drop in ABI after exercise, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Invasive angiography: Not the initial test, reserved for patients with severe PAD or when revascularization is planned.

 

Option C. MRA: Another option for anatomic imaging, but exercise ABI is a less invasive first step.

 

Option D. Segmental lower extremity blood pressure testing: Used to localize PAD, but not necessary as the initial test when the ABI is normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

25% of patients with typical claudication symptoms have a normal or borderline ankle-brachial index.

 

Exercise ABI testing is useful to evaluate for peripheral artery disease in patients with normal ABI values (>0.90 and ≤1.40) and high suspicion of PAD.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with peripheral artery disease (PAD) was prescribed atorvastatin. He has read in a newspaper that statins can cause muscle aches and stopped taking atorvastatin after he developed worsening leg pain upon walking. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atorvastatin

 

Option A:

 

Statin therapy is crucial for secondary prevention in PAD. Reintroducing atorvastatin with proper education about potential side effects and strategies for management is the best approach. Patients with PAD may confuse symptoms of intermittent claudication with adverse effects of statins (myalgia), which may contribute to the low adherence rate. The most appropriate treatment is patient education and reintroduction of atorvastatin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Colestipol (bile acid resin): Not a first-line agent for PAD.

 

Option C. Ezetimibe (cholesterol absorption inhibitor): Monotherapy with ezetimibe is NOT a substitute for statin therapy. Can be used as an add on if LDL-C is not adequately reduced.

 

Option D. Icosapent ethyl (fish oil): Used for triglyceride lowering, which may be considered in addition to statins to lower CV risk (in patients with triglycerides of 135-499 mg/dL).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripheral artery disease is considered a clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

 

Statin therapy is recommended for secondary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease in patients with peripheral artery disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman 2 weeks postpartum presents with chest pain, ST-segment elevation in anterior leads, and elevated troponin. She has no risk factors for atherosclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD)

 

Option C:

 

SCAD is a common cause of myocardial infarction in young women, especially in the peripartum period. The absence of atherosclerotic risk factors and the timing of the event make SCAD the most likely diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atherosclerotic plaque rupture: Unlikely in a young woman with no risk factors.

 

Option B. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: Presents with heart failure symptoms and global LV dysfunction, not ST-elevation.

 

Option D. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy: Typically triggered by stress, often presents with apical ballooning on echo. Common in post-menopausal women (not young women).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spontaneous coronary artery dissection is the most common cause of pregnancy-associated myocardial infarction and occurs most commonly in the first month postpartum

questions.text: A 73-year-old man presents with a 3-hour history of chest pain. His BP is 80/50 mmHg, HR is 120/min and has elevated JVP and clear lungs. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous 0.9% saline

 

Option C:

 

This patient is likely experiencing right ventricular (RV) infarction, a complication of inferior MI. The key features suggestive of RV infarction are hypotension, elevated central venous pressure, clear lungs, and ST-segment elevation in lead V4R. Intravenous fluids are the first-line treatment to increase RV preload and improve cardiac output.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump: Indicated in cardiogenic shock with LV dysfunction, but not the first-line treatment for RV infarction.

 

Option B. Intravenous dobutamine: Inotrope may be considered if fluids are ineffective, but not the initial management.

 

Option D. Oral metoprolol: Beta-blockers can worsen hypotension and should be avoided in RV infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patient with an inferior myocardial infarction with right ventricular involvement and hypotension should receive intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of CABG presents with progressive fatigue, dyspnea, elevated jugular venous pressure with Kussmaul's sign, and a pericardial knock. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Constrictive pericarditis

 

Option C:

 

The presence of Kussmaul's sign (lack of decrease or paradoxical increase in JVP during inspiration), pericardial knock, and signs of right heart failure (elevated JVP, edema, ascites) in a patient with prior cardiac surgery strongly suggest constrictive pericarditis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: Would not present with Kussmaul's sign or pericardial knock.

 

Option B. Chronic liver disease: Can cause ascites and edema but not the other findings.

 

Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Can mimic constrictive pericarditis, but the history of CABG makes the latter more likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kussmaul sign and pericardial knock, if present, are helpful clues to the presence of constrictive pericarditis.

choices.text: Thrombolysis and admission to a telemetry bed
Thrombolysis and transfer to a PCI center
Transfer to a tertiary care center

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with an chest pain, nausea and diaphoresis. ECG is shown. The nearest tertiary care center is 140 minutes away. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thrombolysis and transfer to a PCI center

 

When primary PCI cannot be performed within 120 minutes of first medical contact (FMC), thrombolytic therapy is recommended for STEMI patients. While undergoing thrombolysis, the patient should be transferred to a PCI center for further evaluation and potential rescue PCI if needed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CT angiography: Delays reperfusion therapy, which is crucial in STEMI.

 

Option B. Thrombolyse and admit: Does not allow for timely angiography and potential rescue PCI.

 

Option D. Transfer to tertiary care center: Delays reperfusion and worsens outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with STEMI, thrombolytic therapy is recommended if symptom onset is within 12 hours and PPCI is not available within 120 minutes of FMC.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with severe chest pain for the last 3 hours. She is diaphoretic and appears drowsy. Her BP is 80/60 mm Hg and PR is 60/min. ECG is shown below. She was started on aspirin, clopidogrel and heparin. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Temporary pacing

 

Option D:

 

This patient is presenting with an acute anterior MI complicated by cardiogenic shock and high-grade AV block (Mobitz II).

 

The immediate priority in this situation is to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and address the conduction abnormality. Temporary pacing is the most appropriate next step to provide electrical support and maintain adequate cardiac output until definitive revascularization can be performed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine may be useful for bradycardia but is unlikely to be effective in the setting of high-grade AV block. Additionally, it does not address the underlying myocardial ischemia.

 

Option B. Tenecteplase: While fibrinolysis with tenecteplase may be considered in some STEMI cases, it is not the first-line therapy in this case.

 

Option C. Primary Angioplasty: Primary PCI is the preferred reperfusion strategy for STEMI, but it should be performed after stabilizing the patient's hemodynamics with temporary pacing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior MI related bradyarrhythmias are inherently unstable and need temporary pacing.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents with cardiogenic shock. ECG showed ST depressions in multiple leads and her Troponins were elevated. PCI was performed successfully but she continues to be in cardiogenic shock and she is on aspirin, prasugrel and norepinephrine. Which of the following is the most appropriate additional management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) placement

 

Option B:

 

Treatment of cardiogenic shock initially focuses on reversing the cause of shock, such as reperfusion in the setting of acute coronary syndrome.

 

In cardiogenic shock, appropriate therapies to support cardiac output include inotropes, vasopressors, and mechanical support (such as balloon pumps, percutaneous ventricular assist devices, and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Weak inotrope, unlikely to be effective in cardiogenic shock.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Beta-blocker, contraindicated in cardiogenic shock due to negative inotropic effects.

 

Option D. Urgent cardiac transplantation: Not feasible in the acute setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IABP is a mechanical circulatory support device that can temporarily improve hemodynamics in patients with cardiogenic shock after MI by reducing afterload and improving coronary perfusion.

choices.text: Aspirin plus rivaroxaban plus ticagrelor

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman with a history of NSTEMI and AF underwent a successful PCI with a drug eluting stent. What is the most appropriate management of her antithrombotic therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rivaroxaban plus ticagrelor

 

Option D:

 

The AUGUSTUS trial demonstrated that dual therapy with a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) like rivaroxaban and a P2Y12 inhibitor like ticagrelor resulted in lower bleeding rates without an increase in ischemic events (when compared with triple therapy - DOAC + aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor) in patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) undergoing PCI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspirin plus clopidogrel: This is traditional dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) and does not address the need for anticoagulation in AF.

 

Option B. Aspirin plus ticagrelor: Similar to option a, it lacks anticoagulation for AF.

 

Option C. Aspirin plus rivaroxaban plus ticagrelor: Triple therapy is no longer recommended as it increases bleeding risk without significant additional benefit compared to dual therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among patients with atrial fibrillation who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome, double therapy with clopidogrel or ticagrelor plus a direct oral anticoagulant is recommended over triple therapy with an oral anticoagulant, aspirin, and P2Y12 inhibitor to reduce the risk for bleeding.

choices.text: Severe GERD due to aspirin

questions.text: A 51-year-old male presents with chest pain, 4 days after he was diagnosed with an ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). It is severe, central chest pain with radiation to the trapezius and worse with deep inspiration. The pain woke him from sleep and has improved slightly after getting up out of bed. His Troponin levels were unchanged and ECG showed new saddle-shaped ST elevations in inferior and lateral leads. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early Pericarditis

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation is most consistent with early pericarditis, which is a common complication of STEMI occurring within the first few days after the infarction. The typical features include:

 

  • Chest pain: Sharp, pleuritic (worse with inspiration), and positional (relieved by sitting up or leaning forward).
  • ECG changes: Diffuse ST-segment elevation with a concave or saddle-shaped morphology.
  • Unchanged troponin: Troponin levels are usually not elevated in pericarditis, as it is an inflammatory process and not a myocardial infarction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Recurrent MI: While possible, the unchanged troponin and the specific characteristics of the chest pain make it less likely.

 

Option C. Dressler's Syndrome: This is a post-MI syndrome occurring weeks to months after the infarction, characterized by fever, pericarditis, pleuritis, and leukocytosis. It is too early for this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Severe GERD due to aspirin: GERD can cause chest pain, but the pain is typically burning and not pleuritic. Additionally, the ECG changes are not consistent with GERD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early pericarditis is a common complication of STEMI that typically occurs in the first week after MI.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman experiences shortness of breath after a recent MI that was treated with a drug-eluting stent. Her current medications are aspirin, ticagrelor, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Her physical examination, chest X-ray, and ECG are normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her dyspnea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ticagrelor side effect

 

Option C:

 

Ticagrelor, a P2Y12 inhibitor used in ACS, is commonly associated with dyspnea as a side effect. Given the normal exam, ECG, and chest X-ray, this is the most likely cause.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Heart failure: Unlikely given the normal physical exam and imaging findings.

 

Option B. Stent thrombosis: Usually presents with acute coronary syndrome symptoms and ECG changes.

 

Option D. Ventricular septal rupture: Rare complication of MI, usually presents with shock and a new murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dyspnea is a well-recognized and often self-limited side effect of ticagrelor therapy.

questions.text: Mr. Thiru is admitted after an anterior MI. In the ICU, he has frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) and lab results show S. K of 2.9 mEq/L and S. Mg of 1 mg/dL. Which of the following is NOT indicated in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV lidocaine

 

Option A:

 

In patients with acute MI, frequent PVCs can be a precursor to ventricular fibrillation. Beta-blockers (metoprolol), and correction of electrolyte imbalances like hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, are essential in preventing arrhythmias and reducing mortality.

 

IV lidocaine is an antiarrhythmic drug that is not routinely indicated for suppressing PVCs or asymptomatic non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) in this setting. It may be considered if sustained VT or ventricular fibrillation occurs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Magnesium repletion: Indicated to correct hypomagnesemia, which can trigger arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Beta-blocker, reduces myocardial oxygen demand and helps prevent arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Potassium repletion: Indicated to correct hypokalemia, which can also trigger arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-blockers and correction of electrolyte imbalances re essential in preventing arrhythmias and reducing mortality in acute MI.

questions.text: Which of the following medications should be avoided in patients with an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucocorticoids

 

Option C:

 

Glucocorticoids and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents, with the exception of aspirin, should be avoided in patients with STSTEMI. They can impair infarct healing and increase the risk of myocardial rupture, and their use may result in a larger infarct scar. In addition, they can increase coronary vascular resistance, thereby potentially reducing flow to ischemic myocardium.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is an antiplatelet medication that is beneficial in STEMI. It helps prevent further clot formation and reduces the risk of complications.

 

Option B. Colchicine: Colchicine is an anti-inflammatory medication that can be used in certain cases of pericarditis, but it is not contraindicated in STEMI.

 

Option D. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that reduces heart rate and blood pressure, decreasing the workload on the heart. It is beneficial in STEMI unless there are specific contraindications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NSAIDs (except aspirin) and glucocorticoids are absolutely C/I in STEMI.

choices.text: Discontinue aspirin, continue clopidogrel, and proceed with cataract surgery.
Discontinue clopidogrel, continue aspirin, and proceed with cataract surgery.
Discontinue both aspirin and clopidogrel and proceed with cataract surgery.
Postpone the surgery for 6 months.

questions.text: Mrs. Hinduja, a 64-year-old woman, had a drug-eluting (everolimus) stent placed one month ago for a recent MI. She is on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and clopidogrel. Her ophthalmologist wants to know if these can be stopped for a cataract surgery next week. What is the most appropriate advice?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Postpone the surgery for 6 months.

 

Option D:

 

  • Percutaneous therapy of CAD underwent a paradigm shift with the introduction of coronary stents in 1994. However, metallic stents are also prone to stent thrombosis (1–3%), either acute (<24 hours) or subacute (1–30 days), which can be ameliorated by greater attention to full initial stent deployment and the use of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) (aspirin, plus a platelet P2Y12 receptor blocker [clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor]).  Late (30 days to 1 year) and very late stent thrombosis (>1 year) occur very infrequently with stents but are slightly more common with first-generation drug-eluting stents, necessitating DAPT for up to 1 year or longer.
  • Use of the second-generation stents (such as Mrs. Hinduja’s everolimus-eluting stent) is associated with lower rates of late and very late stent thrombosis, and shorter durations of DAPT may be possible. Premature discontinuation of DAPT, particularly in the first month after implantation, is associated with a significantly increased risk for stent thrombosis (3–9× greater). Stent thrombosis results in death in 10–20% and myocardial infarction in 30–70% of patients.
  • Elective surgery (such as Mrs. Hinduja’s cataract removal) that requires discontinuation of antiplatelet therapy after DES implantation should be postponed until after 6 months and preferably after 1 year, if at all possible. At that point, clopidogrel can be reasonably discontinued if no other mitigating factors are present. If at all possible, aspirin should be continued.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Discontinue aspirin, continue clopidogrel, and proceed with cataract surgery, Option B. Discontinue clopidogrel, continue aspirin, and proceed with cataract surgery and Option C. Discontinue both aspirin and clopidogrel and proceed with cataract surgery: Stopping either or both antiplatelet medications prematurely increases the risk of stent thrombosis and is not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stopping DES in the first 6 months is associated with increased risk of in-stent thrombosis and hence, elective surgeries must be postponed.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with stable heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) is on maximum doses of lisinopril, among other medications. Which treatment is most appropriate to further reduce HF hospitalizations and mortality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Switch lisinopril to valsartan-sacubitril

 

Option D:

 

Valsartan-sacubitril has been shown to significantly reduce mortality and HF hospitalizations in patients with HFrEF compared to ACE inhibitors or ARBs alone. This makes it a preferred treatment option for patients who are already on maximum doses of these medications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Digoxin: While it can reduce HF hospitalizations, it does not improve mortality.

 

Option B. Ivabradine: Used for patients with HFrEF in sinus rhythm and a high heart rate despite beta-blocker therapy. Not applicable here.

 

Option C. Increasing carvedilol: Might not be tolerated well and has not shown the same mortality benefit as valsartan-sacubitril.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valsartan-sacubitril significantly reduces heart failure hospitalizations and mortality in patients with symptomatic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and is recommended in preference to an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker.

questions.text: An 18-year-old athlete experiences cardiac arrest during a race and is successfully resuscitated. Resting ECG is shown. Echocardiogram shows normal LV function but RV dilation and dysfunction. What is the most appropriate management before discharge?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD)

 

Option C:

 

Sudden cardiac arrest with ‘ε’ wave in ECG and RV dysfunction in echo in young athletes raises suspicion for underlying inherited cardiomyopathies, like arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC). An ICD is the most appropriate intervention to prevent sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmias.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: Antiarrhythmic medication, but not as effective as ICD for preventing sudden death.

 

Option B. Genetic testing: Important for diagnosis and family screening, but not the immediate priority before discharge.

 

Option D. Lisinopril: ACE inhibitor for LV dysfunction, not indicated in this case with normal LV function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with sustained ventricular arrhythmias (>30 seconds) or cardiac arrest without a reversible cause have a class 1 recommendation for secondary prevention with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with ascites, pedal edema and elevated JVP. ECG showed low voltage complexes and echo showed increased LV wall thickness. He also has a history of carpal tunnel syndrome. What is the most appropriate test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac MRI

 

Option A:

 

The combination of heart failure, increased wall thickness, low voltage on ECG, and carpal tunnel syndrome raises suspicion for infiltrative cardiomyopathy, like transthyretin amyloid (ATTR) amyloidosis. CMR with gadolinium is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing cardiac amyloidosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Exercise echocardiography: Primarily used to diagnose coronary artery disease.

 

Option C. Right and left heart catheterization: Invasive and not the first-line test for infiltrative cardiomyopathy.

 

Option D. Serum α-galactosidase level: Used to diagnose Fabry disease, which usually causes Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging with gadolinium is highly sensitive and specific for cardiac amyloidosis, but it does not distinguish between AL (immunoglobulin light-chain) amyloidosis and transthyretin amyloidosis.

 

In patients with cardiac magnetic resonance imaging findings consistent with cardiac amyloidosis, an abnormal 99m-technetium pyrophosphate scan would confirm transthyretin amyloidosis without the need for a biopsy.

questions.text: An 8-day postpartum woman presents with acute heart failure symptoms. Echocardiogram shows LV dilation and hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 38%.RV is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peripartum cardiomyopathy

 

Option C:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is characterized by the development of heart failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months postpartum. The presentation of LV dysfunction with no other identifiable cause fits this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute pulmonary embolism: Less likely given normal right heart function on echocardiogram.

 

Option B. Ascending aortic dissection: Usually presents with acute chest pain, and echo would show aortic abnormalities.

 

Option D. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection: Typically presents with chest pain and ECG changes indicative of ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is left ventricular systolic dysfunction with onset toward the end of pregnancy or in the months after delivery in the absence of another identifiable cause; patients often present with features of heart failure.
